title: What will be the approval rating for the Russian government in September 2017?
preds:
Cannibalism reaching new highs in Russia:
http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/25/europe/russia-cannibalism-arrests/index.html
I suppose this isn't much of a forecast at this point...

The state-run media is inundating the news cycle with announcements of positive proactive policies, laws, and measures aimed at boosting the economy, increasing wages, and upping pensioners' payments. Hope springs eternal and will have at least a 1% uptick in the polls, which also follows the monthly 1% point uptick we've seen since April.
Seems the upward trend is continuing.

I suspect it is a bit dangerous not approve the Russian government; 
http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-critics-of-vladimir-putin-who-died-20170325-story.html
The approval ratings has been over 50% in the past decade reaching over 80% recently. Russians believe it their government.
The social indicators seems positive and international mien (toward EU and US) seems popular

every Russian mad about Vlad
could change
later

Putin's approval rating has not been under 60% since 1999.  And I find it odd that so many folks assign a higher probability to "49-50, inclusive" than to "less than 49%".  If Putin's approval nosedives it's much more likely he'll end up somewhere under 49% than just teetering on two percentage points.

Putin has consistently had very strong approval rates over the past years and months. There is no indication that he will have a major drop in popularity or support over the next months or medium-term future.
Reasons for continious strong support: the Russian economy is doing well and this is attributed to Putin, he is perceived as a strong leader who has hold Russia together in the past and continues to rule with a 'hard' hand in order to ensure unity. Russians are proud that their country is again a 'world' power or at least believe that Putin's FP has helped to be recognized again as a strong country. Here are some articles that show the perception of Putin in Russia:
http://www.pewglobal.org/2017/06/20/president-putin-russian-perspective/
https://www.ft.com/content/d2ba19f0-568d-11e7-80b6-9bfa4c1f83d2
http://news.gallup.com/poll/207491/economic-problems-corruption-fail-dent-putin-image.aspx
Russian friends tell me that Russians don't have a cynical & apathetic attitude, but this is election season so Putin is going to make sure that all the news is as positive as possible.

Fitch raises Russian sovereign outlook to positive from stable
http://www.forexlive.com/news/!/fitch-raises-russian-sovereign-outlook-to-positive-from-stable-20170922 "If you can win a foreign election, you can get an upgrade." ?????

The first paragraph should have read: I didn't move the needle enough on the 'More than 50' in last update. The large efforts of the Kremlin to create approval of the Russian government should have effect. The reforms chosen for 2018 were based on the results of the research firm "Romir", the exclusive representative of Gallup International in Russia and the CIS. They think they have found the hot buttons to raise public favorability.  The citations links are the same as in the last update.

I moved the needle too much on the 'More than 50' in last update. However, the large efforts of the Kremlin to create approval of the Russian government should have an effect. The reforms chosen for 2018 were based on the results of the research firm "Romir", the exclusive representative of Gallup International in Russia and the CIS. They think they have found the hot buttons to raise public favor ability.  From other articles (not all websites are secure) we see the degree of work being done to permeate these plans into top of mind awareness of the Russian society: By Ben Aris in Berlin August 25, 2017
"The Russian government has moved from a war budget to an election budget as social spending soars and defence spending is cut. (The government is clearly hoping that a year of largesse will make the voters warm to their president.)" By Vadim Dumes in Paris August 30, 2017
"Russia's Ministry of Economic Development is preparing a roadmap for increasing labour productivity, to be presented at the presidential council on priority projects on August 30, Vedomosti daily reported citing the document. ..The productivity measures will become a part of the economic platform for the re-election of President Vladimir Putin in 2018, Vedomosti said citing unnamed federal sources."  Retrieved from:	http://russia-insider.com/en/politics/russia-moves-war-budget-election-budget/ri20762
https://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2017/09/17_a_10893644.shtml
http://www.intellinews.com/russia-s-government-moves-from-war-budget-to-election-budget-127816/
https://www.vedomosti.ru/economics/articles/2017/04/21/686798-oreshkin-kudrin
http://www.intellinews.com/russian-econmin-tries-to-crack-low-productivity-ahead-of-2018-election-128062/?source=russia
Shifting a little higher to follow the trend of popularity of the last few months.
misread question (Putin's approval vs government approval)

Approval has been increasing every month for the last 6 months according to Levada, but there must be a ceiling somewhere. Last month it was at 50% and it's hard to imagine the trend will continue so steadily for much longer.

The Russian Federation Government agreed on a draft budget for the next three-year plan calling for bills to raising the minium wage and index pensioners payments in 2018 by 3.7%,  "The budget comes from real financial possibilities and is formed in such a way that, under any economic conditions, social obligations will be fulfilled, all the necessary resources in the budget are provided for," said Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. Together with the budget package, said the head of the Ministry of Labor, Maxim Topilin, will also be introduced a bill on raising the minimum wage - the president asked him to develop it last week . The bill will be submitted to the State Duma no later than September 29. Since January 1, it is already planned to fully equalize the minimum wage and the subsistence minimum (as of the second quarter of 2018). As a result of such changes, the Ministry of Labor, Maxim Topilin, stressed, the minimum wage will increase almost twofold in two years.  Source for update:   https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3414655?from=four_economic

The Russian Federation Government agreed on a draft budget for the next three-year plan calling for bills to raising the minium wage and index pensioners payments in 2018 by 3.7%,  "The budget comes from real financial possibilities and is formed in such a way that, under any economic conditions, social obligations will be fulfilled, all the necessary resources in the budget are provided for," said Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. Together with the budget package, said the head of the Ministry of Labor, Maxim Topilin, will also be introduced a bill on raising the minimum wage - the president asked him to develop it last week . The bill will be submitted to the State Duma no later than September 29. Since January 1, it is already planned to fully equalize the minimum wage and the subsistence minimum (as of the second quarter of 2018). As a result of such changes, the Ministry of Labor, Maxim Topilin, stressed, the minimum wage will increase almost twofold in two years.  Source for update:   https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3414655?from=four_economic
Trend is toward 50/51% for the question, based on Levada data.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Public opinion surveys are typically quite wobbly, yet this one has increased every month for the last five months. I would expect it to stabilize a bit by staying flat or dropping slightly.

Approval has been increasing over the past couple of months (+ change for the last 5/7 months), there has been a general increase in the % of people satisfied with direction of country, with a recent drop in % unsure (don't want to make too much of fine scale changes). Social and market confidence measures from Levada are also strong. A one-month range for data that aren't reported in fractions of %s make this a tough call to make. No recent strongly negative news that I saw in a very quick scan of Google News. Torn between 10/30/60 and 10/25/65.

Based on the economic and social indicators being reported by various groups, it seems that it would be hard for the September monthly survey to show improvement over Augusts' 50%. It seems more plausible for responders to hold the same or somewhat less confidant opinion in the government's performance. This would mean holding at 50 or drop 1% point to 49. Something significant would need to occur to drop 2% points to 48. I am basing this on the monthly trend of 1% point monthly increases since April.
Late in forecasting here, but 100% above 50 for the government - seems the trend is gong there
Most everyone is proud Russia is hosting the FIFA World Cup.
Nearly a toss up but given 49-50 is a small range it gets weighted smaller

From August to September, the government approval rating in the poll by VCIOM (which is government-run) was down 0.1% (57.5% to 57.4%). I'd expect the poll by the independent Levada Indicators to move in the same way, i.e., probably not very much.

It's been in the 80s since March 2014. Can't see any reason why it would go lower than 50. Leaving a 3% "anything can happen" margin. (Also, and please let me know in the comments, why would anyone vote for 49-50? It's such a narrow range of possible outcomes.)

Conditional/Circumstantial submissive behavior of human that is driven by power/fear factor plays vital role in political expressions. Faith & Beliefs have been root cause of number of problems and humans that are enjoying life in normal mode (work & live) have less tendency to swing faiths and beliefs. Following is my basis of forecast:

41% Russian Orthodox
25% Spiritual - Higher level of awareness but submissive to conditions
6.5% Muslims - predominantly strong followers of faith and believe
5.6% Christians - that are split on political opinions
Internal politics may be leaning toward highlighting opposition, even with acknowledging corruption, approval stays above 50 and gets stronger toward March 2018.
Russia will propagandize itself to itself as a world leader by taking charge of the North Korean situation.  Unless, of course, the North Koreans blow up a bomb and the nuclear fallout drifts west...
Spent time in Russia, know a little of how they think

Levada index for "situation in country" is quite steady in high 50%s while approval rating quickly oscillates about 50% recently. Hence, quite uniform distribution of prediction with slight preference for higher than 50% rating.
Tweaking my numbers because of positive news about an updated budget and Dmitry Medvedev's being mentioned in the news with an improving economy.
Putins Government is very popular in Russia, outside not so much
The Russian people in general love Mr. Putin.   It seems they admire a strong and virile leader as portrayed by Mr. Putin.   It is all about perception.
Putin is popular (for reasons known only to the people who poll that way) and I believe his popularity and that of the Russian policies will continue to grow.

Historical trend, unless something really bad happens.  Russians are feeling their nationalism.  It would take an absolute disaster in Ukraine or Syria or massive scandal to dent the public opinion below 50%

Putin approval is high which impacts government approval. The other major influence, the economy and issues of scarcity and hardship, will likely not be an issue until during or after winter at the earliest.

Approval for Putin and approval for the Russian Government are linked. I am going to guess that what's different in September is at least in part how Russian citizens now view Trump.  As Putin has gone public with how Trump isn't going to help with the sanctions at this point, citizens now regard him much more unfavorably (see article below).  I agree with @Mathletes regarding the narrow range. That said, does the Government Approval increase or decrease from where it's at now? ( 50% approval vs. 49 disapproval in August) The next 20 days in September are what we're talking about.  I'm guessing an increase over 50% because it's relative to how Russian citizens view Trump vs/ Putin. https://qz.com/1046611/trumps-approval-rating-in-russia-falls-to-just-18-after-the-sanctions-bill/ ....."Now, with his hands tied by Congress over sanctions, Trump is losing out even in Russia. That Pew poll showed that 53% of Russians were confident in Donald Trump in late June. That number is now down to 18% in a survey by Russian state-run pollster VTSIOM held last week just after Congress passed the new sanctions bill, according to Kremlin-friendly news outlet RBC (link in Russian)".... Prime minister Dmitry Medvedev wrote on Facebook that Trump’s administration was showing its “total impotence” by signing the bill, which would result in a “full-scale trade war” and meant that any “hope of improving our relations with the new American administration are finished.”

This is an extremely narrow range.  There is a significant chance that through statistical noise alone the numbers could change.  That means that our tails need to be pretty fat.  Given how there isn't much "news" coming out of Russia that would dramatically change approval ratings, and the fact that other numbers in the Levada report have recently been steady to slightly increasing, I'd put a little more weight on the approval rating moving above 50 rather than dropping below 49.  For staying steady at 49-50, that's a really narrow band, so there just can't be too high a percentage of it hitting there.
Many of the other indicators seem to suggest improving overall sentiment, so expecting slight improvement here as well.
I think the slow but steady improvement over the last few months continues. Not for any deep reason but because its usually safe to assume trends will continue.

Initial forecast based on the last 64 polls in the Putin presidency, and the chances of the Government Approval rating dropping by 2 points or more, dropping by 0 or 1, or increasing. The economy is improving though, so I will need to adjust these numbers for sure.

Mostly a guess following trendlines and correlations with other indicators. From the same Levada Center,interesting poll on the October revolution -Stalinism is alive! :
 https://www.levada.ru/en/2017/04/21/the-october-revolution/ The proximity of the anniversary of the October Revolution is bringing tourism and perhaps a festive ambiance
http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/08/28/the-bolshevik-revolution-is-a-chinese-tourist-trap/ EDIT: Important to note that inflation is a top concern: https://www.rbth.com/politics_and_society/society/2017/09/04/want-to-know-the-truth-about-what-worries-russians-the-most_833370

What russian people more expected from gorvement: low prices for goods and services (import included) - high price bad rating, low price good rating, and attitude to vodka/beer - when goverment make restriction in alcohol is bad rating, when don't take restriction - good rating.
Big influence to this aspect is exchange rate USD/RUR. It is depending from price of crude oil and fed rate. My opinion for september: Price of crude oil will not have big change, fed rate will hike (after CPI growth 09/14/2017,   and USA has too low unemployment like before crisises in 2002 and 2007, fed meeting 09/20/2017).
P.S. autumn more nervous season (autumn 2016, 2015)

Levada's polls shows a small but steady uptick in support for Russia being on the right track, which seems to be slightly correlated with approval for the Russian government, also a slight uptick this summer.  Unforeseen political and economic developments over the next four weeks will probably have an impact of a few points up or down.  One thing to keep an eye on:  In mid-September, Russia will conduct Zapad “West” 2017, a major quadrennial military exercise near the borders of the Baltic States and Poland as well as inside Belarus and of Kaliningrad.  Expect it to get enthusiastic Russian media coverage, which will probably  bump polling for the Russian government.

This question depends on the very slim chance that the Levada Center will not be shut down before this Q is resolved, with all of its staff placed be in jail or sent into exile or planted in boxes.  Stay tuned.
